page.title: 01Moors west of Castleton
page.content: This is an area of predominantly undulating moorland reaching heights of 300m covered by heather and coarse grass. The slopes are cut by springs and streams leading to the River Esk. Most of this area is open grazed by sheep. Grouse and pheasant are found, and grouse butts are provided for shooting. Below 200m some of the moorland gives way to rough pasture, small areas of deciduous trees and occasional fields of sown grass used for hay or silage. The area is used extensively by walkers, hikers and hill runners (some local cross country runs pass through here). The ford in square 10 is a popular place for day trips. There is ample space for parking, picnicing and barbecues. The stream is shallow and a path runs alongside. The small waterfall and
